awd_titl_txt: CRCNS US-German-Israeli Collaborative Research Proposal: Hierarchical Coordination of Complex Actions
awd_abstract_narration:
There are many arenas where humans outperform machines. For example, when coordinated interaction with the physical environment is needed, humans (and animals) vastly out-perform modern robots.  This occurs despite the biological systems having far slower 'hardware' and 'wetware' and much greater complexity than even the most modern robots. This research project seeks to understand the role of complexity in human sensory and motor performance. Human walking under challenging balance conditions will be studied and the use of canes to enhance stability will be included.  The investigators emphasis on learning to balance in challenging environments should lead to new rehabilitation therapies (with or without robotic assistance) to aid recovery of balance and walking (e.g., after stroke). The researchers will create educational units suitable for online presentation to K-12 students and will devise exhibits based on their research for the Museum of Science in Boston.

The central hypothesis to be tested in this project is that complex movements involving physical interaction with objects are organized as a hierarchy formed of modules or primitives. Experiments will study how unimpaired humans learn to walk on narrow beams. Beams of different roundness will vary the challenge. Hand-held canes will alter the available support (like training wheels on a child's bicycle). Computer simulations combined with machine learning will study the benefits and drawbacks of organization as a hierarchy. New mathematical tools will be developed and tested to see if they enable insightful description of human performance in challenging conditions. The research involves a multinational collaboration among scientists from the U.S., Israel, and Germany, each with complementary expertise. The bridge between experimental and theoretical work and the diverse Principal Investigators will help to attract women into the traditionally male-dominated fields of computational neuroscience, robotics and control engineering. Companion projects are being funded by the Federal Ministry of Education and Research, Germany (BMBF) and the US-Israel Binational Science Foundation (BSF).

US-German-Israeli Collaborative Research: Hierarchical Coordination of Complex Actions

Massachusetts Institute of Technology Principal Investigator Neville Hogan

Complex whole-body actions are an essential aspect of our daily life but, for practical expediency, the neuroscience of motor behavior has mostly confined itself to studying simplified movements (e.g. single wrist or finger flexions, reaching in a horizontal plane). While these studies are valuable, the insight they provide may not extend to real-world actions involving whole body coordination and physical interaction with our environment. Embracing the full complexity of real-world actions, this project studied the task of standing and walking on a narrow beam, with and without the support of shoes or canes.

Intellectual Merit

This project was a collaboration among four institutions. The MIT contribution primarily developed the simplest competent mathematical models that could account for and provide insight about the experimental observations. One important goal of this theoretical work was to assess how much of what was observed could be attributed to biomechanical physics and how much reflected neural control.

A distinctive experimental observation was a pronounced anti-correlation of upper-body and lower-body angular momentum. A mathematical model that could reproduce this result showed that this coordination pattern was not a necessary consequence of biomechanics, but reflected a neural choice.

To account for the influence of wearing rigid soles vs. walking barefoot on the beam, we augmented the model to describe the mechanical transmission of ankle torque to force exerted by the foot. Wearing rigid soles enabled more effective exertion of foot force. This mechanical effect (with no neural adaptation) reproduced the main features of the experimental observations: an immediate benefit requiring no period of adaptation; and no persistent after-effect when the rigid soles were removed.

During quiet standing, the foot force vector varies. Any two observations of the sagittal-plane vector component (i.e. oriented fore-and-aft) intersect at a point. Work by others showed that this intersection point was located above the center of mass for low-frequency actions but smoothly descended to move below the center of mass for higher-frequency actions. We developed mathematical models to test whether that behavior was due to biomechanical factors, or neural control. We found that a model of the standing human as a single inverted pendulum (commonly assumed in prior literature) was unable to reproduce this behavior. The simplest competent model was a double inverted pendulum (approximating everything below the hips as one rigid body and everything above the hips as another rigid body).

While the general trend of the intersection point to lie above the center of mass at low frequencies and below it at high frequencies was a consequence of biomechanics, the detailed profile depended on the control system. Remarkably, the best reproduction of experimental observations was consistent with minimizing the control effort needed to balance upright.

We revised this model to account for experimental data obtained from hemi-paretic stroke survivors (with one leg affected), unimpaired elders of similar age, and young unimpaired subjects. We found that the data from unimpaired subjects and the affected limbs of the stroke survivors were all similar, well-described by minimum-effort control. In contrast the nominally-unaffected limbs of the stroke survivors were significantly different: despite the fact that the nominally-unaffected limb had to assume almost the full burden of support, its behavior was not consistent with minimum-effort control.

Broader Impact

Our theoretical and experimental studies included postural support with canes, addressing a sparsely-studied aspect of complex behavior. Our results provide new insights about how humans achieve balance and movement control in complex whole-body tasks involving physical interaction with objects such as tools, a performance still superior to that of modern robots. These insights may contribute to new and more effective robot control algorithms.

In addition to their scientific importance, these results may also have clinical significance. They may inform how older individuals or patients with neural disorders (e.g. stroke or traumatic brain injury) should best use secondary supports. They may lead to new technologies or contribute to new approaches to assist these persons to maintain or recover balance and locomotion. In particular, they may help to clarify which interventions are likely to lead to lasting recovery, and which are not. Interventions that have a predominantly mechanical effect may serve to compensate for impairment but are unlikely to evoke neural change.

Finally, our most recent results may facilitate non-invasive quantitative assessment and early diagnosis of balance deficits in populations at risk of falls, which can ultimately be lethal.

This project contributed to the education of three undergraduate students, two graduate students (one female), and one female post-doctoral associate. They gained first-hand experience of the conduct of scientific engineering research: development of novel instrumentation; formulation of research questions; analysis of experimental data; and presentation of results. The former post-doctoral associate is now junior faculty at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst.
